job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Network- You will learn how to converse with people in a work place setting, show face and "network". If you don't learn how to do these things it will take you forever to get promoted. It's a good skill to have and will serve you well in your career. 
- Impact - The work you are doing does matter. Even small things, if they go wrong, will have a big impact. Attention to detail is important.
- Learning - Great opportunity to learn about the Financial world. Everything you have to learn at first may seem overwhelming but it is worth it.
- People - Willing to help you out or answer any questions at anytime. Just be honest about needing help with something so no errors happen. At Goldman, it always better to ask for help than make a mistake 
- Time Management - Just a lot of things to do everyday. Time Management is a must for success and a good skill to have.
- Office - The have free food here, free gym and it's a hybrid model right now
- Resume Builder - probably the best thing about this company
cons:
Compensation - Unless you work in Investment Banking, the pay at this company is embarrassingly low. You will also have to work 60 hour weeks and get paid half your hourly rate for overtime. If you work out of college, just know that you could be earning more at any other job you apply to, even Dominos. The dedication needed for this job is not worth the pay out. It is obvious this company sees younger employees as interchangeable, so its hard to not see them the same. 
Limited Growth - After 1-2 years on desk you will have learned most of your job. Roles are very niche. If you have any other skills you want to develop, your role will limit you. 
Bonus/Salary Increase - While based on performance is fine, scandals impact your bonus a TON. 
Prestige - Working at this company gets to peoples' heads. 
Button Pushing
Promotions - Take forever. Have to show face and do the most to be up for a promotion. I heard someone say to stand out you should be coming in an hour earlier. Seems to be an outdated mindset. 
WFH - Provided no equipment
Hours - Work life Balance is difficult

pros:
It’s a great time to join the Renewable Power Group at GS. We’re a fast-paced shop that has quickly become the largest C&I solar asset owner in the US.   You’ll be tasked with a lot of responsibility, even as an early-career professional, and expected to deliver day-in and day-out. 

My favorite part of working with the group is being able to bring my authentic self to work everyday and feeling like my voice is heard. The vibe is more similar to a small-shop solar developer than an investment bank, especially in the Boca office. 

Pros:
- Lots of responsibility
- Goldman Sachs brand name
- Constant learning and rapid growth 
- Friendly peers
cons:
Frequent project acquisitions and financial closings can lead to late nights for everyone on the team . . . but you’re working with the best in the industry and learn something new everyday. This is to be expected in a dynamic environment with the level of capital the team has to deploy. 

If you’re looking for something more “chill” with flexible hours, GS and GSRP are probably not for you.

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: It is a name everyone knows about, so it looks great on a resume. Great diversity and inclusion. People work very hard so you often can count on your peers even on weekends and through the night.
cons: They work you a lot of hours. It is important before accepting an offer to understand how many hours the prior person worked so that you can adjust your salary offer to match. If you worked 40 hours at your prior company and they are willing to pay you 20% more for 80-100 hours of work you are making a lot less. A ton less in fact. Know your worth and use the expected hours to negotiate a salary. At this company it is all about your initial salary coming in. I have seen people making 70K less in the same role because of the difference in salary coming in. Raises and everything will be a % of your prior role so you will never catch back up. Also don't take a promotion prior to the beginning part of Q1 (when you know when the raise will take effect). They will only give you the new pay starting then so they will essentially get your working the new role for 9-10 months before any new pay starts. Obviously not employee focused so work your two years and get out. You don't want to be here long term and you will notice quickly great talent doesn't stay.

cons:
Claims to be a tech company but is still a bank at the end of the day. Examples being the push to get employees back in the offices and sticking to strict work deadlines during the pandemic.

There has been a noticeable shift in cost-cutting and reduction of resourcing for multiple years now, especially in the Tech space. Diversity and growth is great, but the firm seems intent on not paying top dollar in new locations which has had an impact on filling roles and attracting top tier talent.

review_title: Toxic and catastrophic; Run for this hills
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Most middle management (e.g. Sr VPs and MDs) are doing everything in their power to keep their people happy/fulfilled and the lights on, but with no help from Mgmt Committee of the firm. They are the only light left across the firm. The last vestiges of the firm’s palpable focus on people and building a community.
cons: Toxic culture; record attrition at every single level and division (particularly the divisions that Solomon sees no value in (e.g. GMD, Engineering, Operations, HCM (HR))); overworked; profoundly underpaid compared to peers; entering expensive new businesses with little return, but acquiring expensive sr. talent to build it out (who ultimately leave within a year or two); Everyone is being advised by mentors and even managers to get out; As one analyst publicly put it: “I’ve been through the foster care system and [Goldman Sachs] is arguably worse.”

pros:
1. The brand - it's feels really cool to say you work for Goldman and watch immediately humble the person on the other end of the conversion

2. The Experience - working for Goldman Sachs will make every other workplace you ever walk into seem lesser than. The work ethic you gain from your time at Goldman is priceless
cons:
1. Cutthroat/Competitive - a lot of the time it will feel like you are fighting to prove your worth. You can't trust anyone (or at least you shouldn't).

2. They don't care about you - "the world is full of people who are just as good at what you do as you and they're probably willing to work more hours for less..." is kind of the mentality.

3. The hours - they're long. You will be "encouraged" not to report overtime, but at the same time you'll love it and be okay with it? This is more of a plus and a con. When you love what you're doing you won't mind working 8 days a week on it.

review_title: Only worth it as a last resort
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good name brand to have on resume, good location if you're lucky enough to be placed in the New York office. Mobility into front office has become a bit easier since many people resigned during COVID.
cons:
Your experience will depend largely on the team that you're placed in, and will vary from very bad to an average, dull job at best. Most managers are worn out from years in this role/industry and you can tell that they're unhappy with their lives. This translates into the role with a culture of under-training, overly high expectations, finger-pointing when there is a mistake, and micromanagement. Teammates are unhelpful and get annoyed when you ask questions, even though there is no other way to learn the job since all of it is very Goldman-specific. They will actively talk about you negatively and assign blame when something goes wrong. Overall, the people make it a very toxic culture. There are a few genuinely good people, but most are only worried about themselves and networking with you so most interactions feel surface-level.

The lack of training may be due to the expectation that there will be high turnover, which creates a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you do stick around and even if your team isn't bad, your job is to do very monotonous, repetitive tasks that would be better off being automated. And, since Goldman uses unique software and your role has such little impact to the company, there's no transferrable skills that you gain for your next role. 

Ops is also treated as the bottom of the totem pole here and it shows. My annual bonus was <5% of my counterparts in front office. You get paid a fraction of what the front office makes, with overtime rate at 0.5x (instead of the usual 1.5x). At this point you're working 10+ hours of overtime per week for less than the NYC minimum wage at around $13/hour. 

My advice: only take this job if you have no other options. Even then, beware that there is a 12-month minimum contract, where you have to pay the (pre-tax) $10,000 relocation bonus back to them. The job was so bad that I considered paying this multiple times so I could leave.

review_title: Operations Analyst - Do Not Work in Ops
pros: Very few pros for working in Ops
cons: GS does not really tell you what it means to work in operations. The salary is very low and you do the work of 5+ different positions for 1/3 the pay of a non Ops role while also doing a majority of the work for the front office teams. Additionally, it is almost impossible to be promoted from within if you accept an Ops role. They only pay half of your hourly rate for overtime and 60+ hour weeks are the standard, so you work half of your week for less than what a fast food worker is being paid per hour.

pros:
-Flat organization (good ideas from an intern are given as much consideration as those from an MD)
-Lots of opportunities to learn; you will not be limited to your job description
-People are generally kind ; encountering "rude" individuals is EXTREMELY rare
-Feedback process; candid, extremely fair and overall a positive experience; more focus on what you do right than what you do wrong
-Excellent growth opportunities; I learned more the first year of my time at the firm than I did the previous five years of my career
-Managers REALLY care about their direct reports and fight for them the best they can
cons:
-Fast paced; everyone thinks their request is the most critical; often impossible to please the majority of your stakeholders
-Long hours; I feel like it's a given - but should be noted. I stopped counting the number of hours I worked years ago because I found it depressing
-Inflexible upper management; staffing is often a problem because upper level management is not supportive of providing the proper number of staff to non-revenue generating divisions (in other words they like to run as lean as possible)

review_title: Can be a great place to start a career depending on the role
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: If you're in a revenue generating role, GS can be a fantastic place to start a career. GS has a knack for attracting bright, ambitious, collaborative people. People earlier in their career can really benefit from a culture of apprenticeship.
cons:
Relative to your peers in the company, compensation can feel arbitrary and is only weakly correlated to your personal performance. For those who put their heads down thinking they'll be paid for doing a great job, be warned that comp is very much driven by perception, favoritism, and the ability of the partner running your team to pull for you at year end. 

The technology in the trading division is generally very outdated. This can be challenging for quants and engineers used to open source and cloud compute. It is a long journey paying down the "tech debt" for building everything in house prior to 2016.

cons: Been at the firm for a long time - things I loved about it have changed under the new CEO. The culture and innovation is not what it used to be

review_title: Goldman Sachs, Ayco Personal Financial Management
pros: Good experience if you want to be a financial planner. 40 hours/week, nothing more or less. Time off, benefits, and HI were high quality. Pay is what you would expect for an entry-level financial analyst position after college, but it never goes up with performance or tenure. Great place to get paid to train, take certification exams, get some experience, and then leave for better opportunities.
cons:
Pay is stagnant. They talk about career progressions and promotions constantly but it's all an illusion, as it takes 3-5 years at a minimum to move up a level and your income never changes (except for a 1-3% increase each year) during that time. Even when you get promoted you are still capped out at a 75k/year total compensation (base and bonus) structure (takes many years to get to that cap) in this department. 

This coaching role at Ayco is really just a stepping stone to gather experience to ultimately leave Ayco, since there is no long-term career for a coach at Ayco that is financially feasible. Accordingly, the turnover is ridiculously high, which should tell you everything you need to know. My team had about 15 people in my region when I started and every last one had left Ayco within two years. Even during that two-year time frame, many people joined and left shortly thereafter. The biggest con is the universal, stagnant pay... every coach gets paid the same (within 5k margin) regardless of performance or experience. Some coaches may perform consistently at a 10% rate compared to other high-performing coaches , but get paid the same as the high-performing coach. However, since turnover is so high, they will never get rid of the poor-performing coaches. Therefore, it seems like the culture is a competition to do as little as possible, but just enough to not get fired (which they would never do). Coaches that actually stick around long enough to understand the compensation will gradually transition into doing as little as possible at work while they look for a new job. 

Management and the internal accounting system are extremely antiquated. You can only get promoted at the end of the year and your pay can only change at the beginning of the year. If you are on the verge of promotion and don't get it, then you have to wait a year before being considered again.

Internally, the organic, progressive career path for a coach would lead to the team leader position. The team leader runs a team of coaches. I have heard from prior team leaders that their pay is still very low (capped at 75k maybe). Additionally, there are very few team leaders for the coaches and very little opportunity for a new team leader position to open up. However, when a team leader position opens up, it seems like Ayco will hire some externally to fill the role, instead of the hundred-plus coaches looking for promotion (even though some coaches are very qualified and tenured).

Very little collaboration. You pretty much just take calls and satisfy your appointments all day, every day once you are out of training. There is very little teamwork and plenty of isolation if you don't create opportunities to meet and socialize with your colleagues. 

High burnout rate from doing the same thing over and over again all day. Nothing ever changes meeting-to-meeting, day-to-day, week-to-week, etc...

review_title: Goldman Sachs cheated me out of a portion of my 2020 total compensation
job_title: Vice President of Technology in New York, NY
pros: may look good on a resume but hopefully not
cons:
I was employed at Goldman Sachs for 22 months. Part of my total compensation for 2020 was an equity component which represented 15% of my total bonus. One needs to be mindful of the fact that at Goldman Sachs, the bonus makes up a significant chunk or one's total compensation. Other financial companies pay higher base salaries than Goldman Sachs so Goldman tries to make up for the difference with a higher bonus.
I had worked for Goldman Sachs before, from 10/2004 through 5/2012. Part of my compensation back then was also paid in RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) which vested over the course of three years. Back then, it was also acknowledged that if I were to leave the company, I would forfeit unvested RSU, unless I was over the age of 50.
This time around, the rules for equity compensation have changed. The Equity Component was vested immediately, but could not be exercised for a number of years.
Interestingly, when I started investigating this issue in greater detail, I discovered that the last leg of my equity compensation component could not be exercised until 2050. It is most likely that I would not even be alive by then.
In November 2021, I received a correspondence from GS stating that I needed to certify my equity component. Failure to do so would result in immediate forfeiture. I complied and retained this correspondence for my records. One of the mandatory fields in the certification form was the name of my present employer. I specified my present employer as Bank of America. Note that my current job at Bank of America has absolutely nothing in common to the job I was doing at Goldman Sachs. Bank of America has over 200,000 employees who perform a myriad of activities that are completely unrelated to what other employees may be doing at Goldman Sachs.
On January 19, 2022, I received a letter from Goldman Sachs stating that all of my RSUs granted as part of my 2020 total compensation package were forfeited because according to RSU agreement paragraph 11(a), it was deemed that I associated with a “Competitive Enterprise" after departure from the company.
Anyone who is still working or thinking of joining Goldman Sachs needs to be aware that the only way their Equity Compensation component could be worth anything is if they were to stay at the company for many years.

SVN widely used 
Few teams use cloud technologies

Business looks down on tech. Tech people, 2nd class citizens 
Every opportunity used to lower costs (open offices in Birmingham, Stockholm for Europe, other small cities in US, move work to India)
